title: Public Awareness Campaigns
summary:
Key ideas:
- Public awareness campaigns have a long history of failure as well as success.
- Research on anti-rape campaigns aimed at men has zero evidence of effectiveness.
- Some successful public awareness campaigns include MADD’s campaign against drunk driving and seatbelt awareness campaigns.
- Stigmatizing campaigns can be counterproductive and cause resentment in those who are forced to endure them.
- The author believes it is difficult to predict the success or failure of future public awareness campaigns.

Key learnings:
- Tobacco and anti-drunk driving campaigns work using very graphic images of bad outcomes.
- Employing stigma can be successful, but not always.
- Captive audiences, as in DARE and sex education programs, are more likely to be counterproductive.

Key questions:
- Why do some public awareness campaigns work and others fail?
- What types of negative feelings from campaigns are more likely to be counterproductive?
- Can promoting public awareness campaigns lead to resentment in the groups they target?
- How can the success or failure of future public awareness campaigns be predicted?
